Graphical abstract The structurally ordered low-Pt compounds (PtNi3-C and PtFe3-C) were synthesized via the chemical reduction method and the toluene catalytic oxidation experiments were conducted to test their catalytic performance. And the reaction kinetics and catalytic mechanism are investigated based on the MVK model. The low-Pt bimetal compounds (PtNi3-C and PtFe3-C) were synthesized via the chemical reduction method and the toluene catalytic oxidation experiments were conducted to test their catalytic performance. The sample of PtFe3-C (T100 = 255 ℃) possessed a better low-temperature catalytic activity than PtNi3-C (T100 = 288 ℃) due to a higher content of Pt (0), while both two catalysts had a desirable catalytic stability (⁓100 % within 72 h). The reaction kinetic parameters were acquired from the Mars-van Krevelen (MVK) model, and the MVK mechanism combined with the in-situ DRIFT was used to investigate the reaction pathway. Moreover, the theoretical calculations based on DFT was applied to study the accessibility of toluene to the surface of metal atoms doping. Herein, this study not only can provide a promising catalyst with the superior low-temperature catalytic activity and stability, but also can give a comprehensive understanding on the toluene catalytic oxidation mechanism over bimetal catalysts. Keywords Low-Pt catalysts Toluene oxidation Kinetic model The Mars-van Krevelen mechanism Theoretical calculations 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs), such as acetone, toluene and benzene, which not only can threaten human health, but also can destroy the ozone layer and ecological environment [1–3]. Adsorption, catalytic oxidation and condensation techniques have been developed to decrease the concentration of emitted VOCs [4–6]. Among them, catalytic oxidation is that VOCs can be highly converted to be CO2 and H2O at low temperature under the addition of O2 and action of catalyst. This method has the advantages of low reaction temperature, low energy consumption, high purification efficiency, no secondary pollution and strong applicability [7–9]. In general, the commonly used catalysts in VOCs catalytic oxidation can be divided into two types, namely noble metal catalysts and non-noble metal oxides catalysts [10–14]. The noble metal catalyst exhibits an excellent catalytic activity and stability, while expensive costs and the likelihood of poising devitalization may limit its industrial applications [15]. Non-noble metal oxides catalysts are basically low-cost and possess the anti-poisoning ability compared to the former, but they are less efficient resulting in more energy expenditures [16,17]. Incorporating 3d transition metals into the noble metal crystal is considered as a promising strategy to reduce costs and improve the catalytic activity [18–20]. This can be attributed to the decrease of the noble metal content and the adjustment of its surface electronic structure [21]. Recently, there are several studies on VOCs catalytic oxidation over Pt-M (M = Fe, Ni, Co and Cu) alloys, while they were mainly on Pt-rich materials [22,23]. Wang et al. prepared PtRu catalysts by wet impregnation method and tested its catalytic oxidation performance on chlorobenzene, revealing a higher catalytic activity and stability compared to monometallic Pt and Ru catalysts [24]. Huang et al. synthesized PtCo nanoparticles supported on the graphene nanosheet through a hydrothermal strategy, which showed a good catalytic performance of methanol oxidation [25]. However, the research on the VOCs catalytic oxidation over low-Pt compounds has rarely been reported due to the difficulties in catalysts synthesis [26]. Therefore, the preparation method of low-Pt catalysts needs to be further explored. Toluene as a typical VOC has received extensive attentions in recent years, and many researchers have investigated the reaction pathway and kinetics of toluene catalytic oxidation over metal catalysts [27–29]. For example, He et al. summarized the recent advances in the catalytic oxidation of various VOCs including toluene, indicating that the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H), Eley-Rideal (E–R) and Mars-van Krevelen (MVK) models are the most applicable models used for the VOCs catalytic oxidation [30]. Kim et al. explored the reaction kinetics of toluene oxidation over Ce/Cu/γ-Al2O3 using the MVK model, and the simulation result presented an apparent activation energy of 63.1 kJ/mol [31]. Radic et al. synthesized Pt/Al2O3 catalysts with different platinum crystallite sizes, and investigated the reaction kinetics of n-hexane and toluene oxidation based on the MVK model. They reported that catalysts containing larger Pt crystallites possessed the lower activation energy, which is beneficial for the oxidation reaction [32]. Genuino et al. prepared several Mn and Cu-Mn mixed oxides and revealed that their catalytic pathways on the toluene oxidation can be explained by the MVK mechanism [33]. Nevertheless, which should be noticed is that the catalysts used in above studies are metal oxides based catalysts, there were few researches on exploring the reaction mechanism of toluene oxidation over bimetal catalysts. Many synthesis methods can be used to prepare bimetallic nanoalloys (NAs), but these generally suffer from their considerable complexity, lack of scalability, and often harsh chemical or physical conditions [34]. Comparatively, the organic phase reduction method was widely used in the synthesis of bimetallic nanoalloys due to its simple and safe operation and broad applicability. In this study, the low-Pt bimetal compounds of PtNi3 and PtFe3 are synthesized via the method of organic phase reduction, and then they are supported on the carbon black to obtain the samples of PtNi3-C and PtFe3-C. There are two reasons for using the XC-72 carbon black. On the one hand, the as-synthesized samples of PtFe3 and PtNi3 can be dispersed evenly over the XC-72 carbon black, and there were many researches has used it as the support of the noble metal catalyst [21]. On the other hand, the use of carbon black can reasonably ignore the influence of the support, so that we can directly study the reaction mechanism of toluene oxidation over bimetal catalysts. The catalytic oxidation activity and stability under different toluene concentrations of as-prepared samples are studied on a laboratory-scale reaction bench. Furthermore, the reaction kinetics and catalytic mechanism are investigated, and the DFT calculation was used to study the interaction between toluene and the surface of bimetal catalysts, which can provide a better understanding of the toluene catalytic oxidation over low-Pt catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Raw materials Platinum acetylacetonate (Pt(acac)2, 97 %), iron acetylacetonate (Fe(acac)3, 98 %), nickel acetate tetrahydrate (Ni(ac)2·4H2O, 99.9 %), benzylether (95 %), tetradecanediol (TDD, 90 %), hexadecanediol (98 %), oleylamine (80–90 %), oleic acid (AR), dichlorobenzene (>99.9 %) and trioctylamine (95 %) were purchased from Aladdin. Hexane (>97 %) and toluene (95 %) were purchased from Sinopharm. The XC-72 carbon black (CB) was purchased from Cabot and absolute ethyl alcohol (>99.7 %) was purchased from Hengxing. The gas supplies including nitrogen (99.99 %), oxygen (99.99 %), air (21 vol% O2, 79 vol% N2), hydrogen (99.99 %) and argon (99.99 %) were purchased from High-Tech Gas, China. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The chemical reduction method can be applied to prepare the metallic alloy [35,36]. To synthesize the sample of PtNi3-C, as shown in Fig. 1 a, 0.6 mmol Ni(ac)2·4H2O, 105 mg TDD, 0.45 mL oleylamine, 0.45 mL oleic acid were added into 35 mL benzylether in a threeneck flask, and then the solution was heated to 100 ℃ for 1 h in Ar to remove the remaining water. Sequently 0.2 mmol Pt(acac)2 in 0.15 mL dichlorobenzene was injected into the reaction vessel when the temperature increased to 200 ℃ and lasted for 1 h in Ar. After the reaction solution cooled down to room temperature naturally, 30 mL absolute ethyl alcohol mixed with the reaction solution were centrifuged at 11,000 rpm for 15 min to isolate the PtNi3 nanoparticles (NPs). Then the mixture of PtNi3 NPs, 30 mL hexane and XC-72 carbon black were treated with ultrasound to meet a nominal PtNi3 content of 7 wt.% and centrifuged at 11,000 rpm for 15 min. The obtained materials were dried at 40 ℃ for 12 h in a vacuum oven to acquire the sample of PtNi3-C. Similarily, to synthesize the sample of PtFe3-C, as shown in Fig. 1b, the mixture of 0.125 mmol Pt(acac)2, 0.375 mmol Fe(acac)3, 0.25 mL oleic acid and 1 mmol hexadecanediol were immersed in 20 mL trioctylamine and held at 330 °C for 1 h in Ar, and other treatments including centrifugation and the dispersion of XC-72 carbon black were similar to the synthetic process of PtNi3-C. 2.3 Catalyst characterizations High-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, Hitachi JEM-2100 F) was used to characterize the surface morphology of the sample. Chemical compositions and valence states of the sample were identified by energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX, attached to TEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB250Xi). X-ray diﬀ ;raction (XRD, D8 Advance) was applied to analyze the crystal phase of the sample. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) was used to explore the element content of as-obtained samples. The in-situ DRIFT testing was carried out by a Nicolet IS 50 FTIR spectrometer with a total gas flow (20 vol% O2/Ar) of 40 mL min−1, and the test data were acquired at a resolution of 8 cm−1 in the range of 650- 4000 cm−1. 2.4 Catalytic tests The experimental facility of toluene catalytic oxidation is shown in Fig. 2 . The toluene catalytic oxidation was carried out in a tubular furnace with a quartz tube (i.d. = 7 mm, length = 650 mm), and the reaction temperature was controlled by a temperature-control instrument. The temperature of toluene solution was stabilized by an ice-water bath, while the toluene concentration was adjusted by controlling the gas flow using mass flow controllers. The gas chromatography (GC-9860-5CNJ, Haoerpu, China) was used to detect the toluene concentration before and after the reaction. Before the catalytic experiment, 30 mg catalysts and about 1000 mg quartz sand (80 mesh) were mixed evenly and put into the quartz tube, while the total gas flow (20 vol% O2, N2 as balance) was 160 mL min−1 to meet a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 12,000 h−1. Different toluene concentrations of 400, 700 and 1000 ppm were obtained by controlling the N2 flow. The toluene conversion (λ) was tested at the temperature range of 120−300 °C, which was calculated by Eq. (1): (1) λ = C i n − C o u t C i n × 100 % where Cin and Cout refer to the toluene concentration of the inlet and outlet, respectively. 2.5 Simulation methodology The CASTEP code (Cambridge Sequential Total Energy Package) based on density functional theory (DFT) was performed for the theoretical calculations [37]. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) via the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) formula was applied to calculate the exchange–correlation potential. The cutoﬀ ; energy for plane-wave expansions was 400 eV. Geometry optimization of the structures was carried out with the Broyden–Fletcher–Goldfarb–Shanno (BFGS) algorithm, and parameters used to converge simulation structures for all models were set as followings: energy change per atom 1 × 10−3 eV/atom, maximum force 0.05 eV/Å, maximum stress 0.1 GPa, and maximum displacement 2 × 10−3 Å. In geometry optimization, the model of Ni-Pt alloy was acquired by replacing a Ni atom by a Pt atom at the top layer of the model of Ni, and the model of Pt-Ni alloy was obtained by replacing a Pt atom by a Ni atom at the top layer of the model of Pt. In all cases, the model surface is constructed with a 3 × 3 × 1 supercell and a at least 10 Å vacuum region was employed. In addition, the top layer and the adsorbates are relaxed and the other layers are fixed in geometry relaxation. The adsorption energy of toluene was calculated by Eq. (2): (2) Eads = Etoluene+catalyst– Ecatalyst – Etoluene where Eads, Etoluene+catalyst, Ecatalyst, and Etoluene represent the adsorption energy, total energy of reaction system, energy of the catalyst surface and energy of toluene molecules, respectively [4]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance Fig. 3 displays the catalytic performances of as-synthesized samples under different toluene concentrations of 400 ppm (Fig. 3a), 700 ppm (Fig. 3b) and 1000 ppm (Fig. 3c). Note that the carbon black (CB) as the blank sample shows a negligible impact on the toluene conversion in three concentrations, while the samples of PtNi3-C and PtFe3-C present outstanding catalytic performances, indicating the main active sites are located on metallic surfaces. When the concentration of toluene is 400 ppm, toluene conversions of PtNi3-C and PtFe3-C achieve 100 % at about 255 ℃. And when the toluene concentration is increased to 700 or 1000 ppm, the temperature at which toluene is completely oxidized for PtNi3-C and PtFe3-C is 288 and 255 ℃, respectively. As shown in Fig. S1, the figures of CO2 yield showed a similar trend with the figure of toluene conversion, which is consistent with previous studies [38], showing a superior performance of as-prepared catalysts. The experimental results reveal that two obtained samples possess superior toluene catalytic performances at a low reaction temperature, and the sample of PtFe3-C has a higher catalytic activity than PtNi3-C under a higher toluene concentration. Besides the toluene conversion, the catalytic stability is an important index for applying the developed catalysts to practical uses. To further explore the catalytic performance of as-prepared catalysts, the stability experiments were carried out at 288 ℃ (PtNi3-C) and 255 ℃ (PtFe3-C) under a certain GHSV of 12,000 h−1 and a toluene concentration of 1000 ppm. The results show that the toluene conversion of PtNi3-C (Fig. 4 a) and PtFe3-C (Fig. 4b) can keep above 99.5 % at least 72 h, revealing an excellent catalytic stability of as-synthesized materials. Considering water is an indispensable component in the real exhaust gas, the presence of water will reduce the catalytic efficiency due to water molecules occupy more active sites on the catalysts surface [15]. In this study, the effect of different water contents (3.5 vol. % and 7 vol. %) on toluene catalytic oxidation over PtFe3-C and PtNi3-C were explored. As shown in Fig. 4c and d, when the reaction temperature was located near the optimum catalytic temperature for two catalysts, different water contents showed different degrees of activity inhibition to toluene oxidation. And when the temperature rose to the optimal-anhydrous conversion temperature (288 ℃ for PtNi3-C and 255 ℃ for PtFe3-C), the two catalysts achieved only about 95 % toluene conversion. Above results can be ascribed to the competitive adsorption between water vapor and toluene, water molecules occupy more active sites on the catalyst surface than toluene [13]. However, when the water content was 7 vol. %, the catalytic efficiency of PtNi3-C at 290 ℃ and PtFe3-C at 260 ℃ can still reach more than 90 %, which indicated a good water-resistance for two catalysts. Based on experimental results, the sample of PtFe3-C exhibits an outstanding toluene catalytic performance when GHSV is 12,000 h−1. Considering longer residence time may favor the catalytic reaction, two higher GHSV (24,000 h−1 and 36,000 h−1) were also conducted to test the effect of gas velocity on the catalytic activity of PtFe3-C. At a total gas flow of 240 mL min−1, 30 mg PtFe3-C and about 720 mg quartz sand were used to meet a GHSV of 24,000 h−1, while 30 mg PtFe3-C and about 470 mg quartz sand were used when GHSV was 36,000 h−1. As shown in Fig. 5 , 100 % toluene conversion under a higher GHSV for PtFe3-C is still obtained at 255 ℃, which is almost the same as that with a GHSV of 12,000 h−1, indicating an admirable low-temperature catalytic performance of PtFe3-C. 3.2 Characterization of catalysts As shown in Fig. 1, the method of organic phase reduction is used to synthesize the sample of PtNi3-C and PtFe3-C. During the preparation procedures, Pt(acac)2 and Ni(ac)2·4H2O (or Fe(acac)3) participate in the reaction as metal precursors, and benzyl ether or trioctylamine acts as the solvent. TDD or hexadecanediol plays the role of reductant to reduce the metal organic salt, while oleylamine and oleic acid act as capping agents to regulate chemical reactions [35,36]. After a simple synthetic reaction, the PtM3 (M = Ni or Fe) can be supported on the carbon black through the treatments of ultrasound, centrifugation, and vacuum drying. Fig. 6 a-d shows the TEM images of PtNi3-C and PtFe3-C, in which the black dots represent the PtNi3 and PtFe3 NPs, while the gray transparent areas represent the carbon black support, indicating that metallic NPs are uniformly dispersed on the carbon support. The size distribution analysis indicates that PtNi3 possesses a larger particle size (10.10 ± 6.10 nm) than PtFe3 (8.08 ± 3.47 nm) (Fig. 6b and d). HRTEM images (Fig. 6e and g) are applied to further explore the atomic-scale structures of as-synthesized samples, which reveal a dominant face-centered cubic (FCC) structure [39]. The images of fourier fast transform (FFT) and inverse fourier fast transform (IFFT) (Fig. 6f and h) indicate the presence of the (111) crystal plane. Besides, the (111) interplane distance of pure Pt, Ni and Fe is 2.27 Å, 2.03 Å and 1.98 Å, respectively, while the (111) interplane distance of PtNi3 and PtFe3 is around 2.10 Å and 2.04 Å in this study, respectively, proving the formation of the alloy phase in as-prepared materials [40]. Furthermore, the elemental mappings of PtNi3-C and PtFe3-C (Fig. 6i and j) show a uniform elemental distribution of C, Pt, Ni or Fe, and there is no obvious preferential segregation on the surfaces of two samples. And the results of ICP show the atomic ratio of PtFe3 and PtNi3 is 28:77 and 19: 67, respectively, indicating the successful synthesis of PtM3. Fig. 7 a displays the XRD patterns and both two samples exhibit an obvious diﬀ ;raction peak at about 43.1°, corresponding to the (111) crystal plane [41]. Note that, compared to Pt (111) (2θ of 39.5°), a positive diffraction peak shift of PtNi3-C and PtFe3-C presents, which can be attributed to the intercalation of Ni or Fe NPs. The EDX patterns are investigated on a copper wire mesh, confirming the existence of C, Pt and Fe (or Ni) in PtFe3-C (or PtNi3-C) samples (Fig. 7b). Moreover, XPS is used to characterize the surface chemistry before and after the catalytic reaction. As shown in Fig. 4c-f, the binding energy (BE) peaks situated at 856.7 and 874.1 eV are related to the spin-orbitals of Ni 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 for PtNi3-c (Fig. 7c) respectively, while the peaks located at 711.5 and 724.9 eV are respectively connected to Fe 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 for PtFe3-C (Fig. 7e) [42,43]. And the peaks of Pt 4f7/2 and 4f5/2 are located at about 71.7 and 75.1 eV for two samples, which are related to the presence of metallic Pt(0) [44]. Furthermore, there is no obvious change in the peak position of Ni, Fe and Pt before and after the toluene catalytic oxidation reaction, showing a favorable stability of as-synthesized catalysts. 3.3 The Kinetic models of the reaction The reaction rate of toluene catalytic oxidation is defined in Eq. (3): (3) − r t o l u e n e = λ w c / f t o l u e n e , i n Where λ , w c , f t o l u e n e , i n is the toluene conversion, the weight of used catalysts, inlet molar flow rate of the toluene, respectively. The results of toluene catalytic oxidation reaction rate are displayed in Table 1 , and there is a significant positive correlation between the reaction rate and the temperature for two samples. The main reason for this relationship can be explained by the collision theory. When the temperature increases, there will be more efficient collisions between activated molecules, resulting in an increase of reaction rate [45]. The MVK model has been widely used in the kinetic modeling of benzene, toluene or other hydrocarbons catalytic oxidation reactions [45], which can be expressed as Eqs. (4) or (5): (4) − r t o l u e n e = k O 2 k t o u l e n e C t o l u e n e C O 2 k O 2 C O 2 + γ k t o u l e n e C t o l u e n e (5) 1 − r t o l u e n e = γ k O 2 C O 2 + 1 k t o u l e n e C t o l u e n e where k O 2 , k t o u l e n e represents the catalyst reoxidation and the rate constant of toluene oxidation, respectively; C O 2 , C t o l u e n e is O2 and toluene concentration in the gas stream, respectively; and γ is equal to 9 and represents the stoichiometric coefficient of O2 in C7H8 + 9O2 → 7CO2 + 4H2O. Note that the concentration of toluene is much smaller than O2, so the term of γ k O 2 C O 2 can be assumed to be constant A. Eq. 5 can be simplified as Eq. 6: (6) 1 − r t o l u e n e = A + 1 k t o u l e n e C t o l u e n e And the Arrhenius equation is commonly used to calculate the apparent activation energy of catalytic reactions, which can be expressed as Eq. 7 in this case: (7) k t o u l e n e = k 0 exp ( − E a R T ) where k0 is the pre-exponential factor, Ea is the apparent activation energy, R is the equal to 8.314 × 10−3 kJ/ (mol‧ K), while T is the reaction temperature (K). The results calculated by the above equations based on the experimental data of PtNi3-C and PtFe3-C are shown in Table 2 . As shown in Table 2, the rate constant of toluene oxidation ktoluene increases with increasing temperature, which is consistent with the description of the Arrhenius equation (Eq. 7). The Ea of PtFe3-C (241.44 kJ mol−1) is lower than that of PtNi3-C (272.80 kJ mol−1), which shows the former exhibits a higher catalytic activity of toluene oxidation, corresponding to the experimental data [46]. Furthermore, Arrhenius proposed that the reaction starts only when collisions occur between molecules with the high enough energy, namely the activated molecules. And the reaction occurs easier when the effective collision times increase, suggesting that the value of the pre-exponential factor can be used to characterize the effective collision times. The calculated value of k0 is up to 1.01 × 1031 or 5.45 × 1027 s−1, revealing a violent toluene oxidation reaction [31,45]. Furthermore, a relatively high value of R2 reveals a good fitness for Arrhenius equation and reflects the rationality of the MVK model applied in this study. Besides the reaction kinetics analysis, in general, the catalytic performance of Pt-based catalysts is depended on the proportion of Pt(0), and a high Pt loading can give a better catalytic activity [46,47]. And the noble metal catalyst used catalysts in toluene oxidation exhibits an excellent catalytic activity and stability, which can be attributed to two reasons. On the one hand, the noble metal catalyst such as Pt has unique surface electronic structures and d orbitals, which results in forming a coordination bond with reactants to participate in the reaction [25]. On the other hand, the noble metal catalyst possesses good absorption and desorption ability, which promotes the surface reaction with toluene. As a result, the catalytic performance of Pt-based catalysts is depended on the proportion of Pt (0), and a high Pt loading can give a better catalytic activity. The XPS results show the state of Pt in PtM3 is almost Pt (0), and the weight ratio of Pt/PtNi3 and Pt/PtFe3 calculated from ICP is 0.38 and 0.45, respectively. Consequently, the higher Pt (0) content of PtFe3-C results in a higher catalytic performance at low temperature. 3.4 Reaction mechanism The L–H, E–R and MVK models are generally applied to investigate mechanisms of VOCs (benzene, toluene, propane, etc.) catalytic oxidation reactions. Among them, the MVK model is widely used for illuminating the mechanism of hydrocarbon catalytic oxidation [30]. The MVK model assumes that VOCs molecules are firstly adsorbed to the catalyst surface and then react with active oxygen species (superoxide, peroxide and lattice oxygen), leading to the reduction of the metallic catalyst and the formation of oxidation intermediates. Subsequently, the metallic catalyst is regenerated through the oxidation process by oxygen species in the feed gas to complete a cycle [48]. Take the toluene catalytic oxidation as an example, processes of the MVK mechanism can be described as follows: (8) T ouluene + C a t a l y s t → C a t a l y s t − T ouluene (9) O 2 + V O * → O a c t i v e − V O * (10) C a t a l y s t − T o l u e n e + O a c t i v e − V O * → C a t a l y s t + V O * + C O 2 + H 2 O where VO* represents oxygen vacancies and Oactive is active oxygen species. And the active oxygen species can be obtained by the combination of O2 and VO*, so oxygen vacancies on the surface of the catalyst play a key role in the toluene catalytic oxidation. Based on the above analysis and the MVK mechanism, several researches relied on the MVK model to explain the mechanism of toluene catalytic oxidation (Fig. 8 a). G o ´ mez et al. explored that the lattice oxygen played a major role in toluene oxidation, while oxygen vacancies were mainly on the surface of Co3O4. And the synergistic effect of Co3O4 and CeO2 can improve the catalytic performance [49]. Peng et al. reported that [48] the surface of Pt/CeO2-r possessed more oxygen vacancies than that of Pt/CeO2-c, leading a better catalytic performance (T90 = 150 ℃), while the concentration of oxygen vacancies was rested with the shape of CeO2. In addition, Carabineiro et al. used the MVK model to explain the reaction pathway of toluene catalytic oxidation. The catalytic activity of mixed oxides was superior to single oxide because the former can increase the reducibility of surface oxygen, while appropriate surface acidity of the catalyst can also enhance the catalytic performance [50]. Dou et al. reported that the higher concentration of oxygen species and Cu2+ in CCZ/T resulted in a better performance of toluene oxidation (T100 = 275 ℃). Meantime, the existence of lattice oxygen species can remarkably accelerate the conversion of toluene through the analysis of the MVK mechanism [51]. The applicability of the MVK mechanism in catalytic oxidation of toluene over several MnO2 catalysts was also confirmed by Lyu et al. [52]. The in-situ DRIFT was applied to investigate the reaction pathway, which exhibited that the plentiful oxygen vacancies and redox couple Mn3+/Mn4+ were dominant factors to an outstanding catalytic performance (MnO2-Ac, T90 = 200 ℃). Herein, the catalytic activity of toluene is depended on several factors, the concentration of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface has a decisive effect on the process of toluene oxidation, while the other factors such as surface acidity and specific areas of the catalyst can also play non-negligible roles in improving the catalytic activity. Note that all the above studies used XPS to characterize the presence of active oxygen species, which can be divided into lattice oxygen and absorbed oxygen. However, in this study, as shown in Fig. 8b, the result of XPS indicated that there are only surface absorbed oxygen species existed on the surface of as-synthesized PtFe3-C catalyst, including O2 2−, O2−, O− and OH group [51]. Furthermore, the carbon black support showed few toluene oxidation effect, so the main active sites are located on PtFe3 surfaces. The schematic diagram of catalytic oxidation of toluene over PtFe3-C can be depicted as Fig. 8c. At first, toluene is oxidized to intermediates such as benzoyl oxide species, which can be attributed to the fracture of weak C–H bonds by absorbed oxygen on the surface of PtFe3. Meanwhile, oxygen vacancies on the surface of PtFe3 are released, which can speed up the transformation of O2 to active oxygen species. Afterwards, the catalyst is reoxidized and oxygen vacancies are filled with O2 in the feed gas. In addition, the in-situ DRIFT is used to further investigate the reaction progress of toluene catalytic oxidation over PtFe3-C (Fig. 8d). The spectra at two different temperatures are acquired after PtFe3-C reacted with toluene for 20 min. At the temperature of 120 ℃, there is only a small fraction of toluene oxidized by PtFe3-C catalyst, which is similar to previous studies [52]. The bands at 1029, 3036 and 3083 cm−1 are connected to plane bending vibrations and stretching vibration of C–H groups in aromatic ring, while the weak bonds at 1080 and 1153 cm−1 correspond to CO stretching vibration. The bands at 1452, 1498 and 1608 cm−1 are ascribed to benzene ring deformations vibration [38,53], and the bands at 2782, 2883 and 2935 cm-1 are assigned to CH stretching vibration of methylene groups [54]. When temperature raises to 240 ℃, it is obvious that toluene has been oxidized. The reaction between the surface of PtFe3-C and toluene may lead to the formation of alkoxide species, so strong bonds appear at 1080 and 1195 cm−1 [55]. And the weak bonds at 1346 and 1380 cm-1 may be caused by the symmetric bending vibration of methyl [52]. Interestingly, the emergence of 1540 cm-1 and surrounding three bonds indicate the formation of carboxylate groups, revealing the benzoate species is a key intermediate during the process of toluene catalytic oxidation. The bonds at 1639 and 2332 cm−1 corresponding to H2O and CO2 respectively show that the intermediates are completely oxidized. Furthermore, the bonds at 1717−1778 cm−1 are ascribed to anhydride species [56]. Based on the in-situ DRIFT analysis and the MVK mechanism, the reaction pathway of toluene catalytic oxidation over PtFe3-C catalysts can be designed as Fig. 8e. In the first place, toluene is absorbed to the surface of the catalyst, and the C–H bond of the methyl group is destroyed by the absorbed oxygen, which forms benzyl oxides species (C6H5−CH2−O) on the surface of PtFe3-C. Subsequently, the benzyl oxides species are oxidized to benzoate species. Secondly the aromatic ring of toluene is broken to form anhydride species and other carboxylate compounds, and the other intermediates are completely oxidized to CO2 and H2O. At the same time, the surface of the PtFe3-C catalyst is reoxidized and oxygen vacancies are exposed to O2 in the feed gas to fill consumed active oxygen species. 3.5 DFT calculations To further study the accessibility of toluene to the surface of metal atoms doping, the CASTEP code based on DFT is applied to theoretical calculations. And the simulation results are displayed as Fig. 9 , in which the model of Ni (211)-Pt alloy possesses a higher adsorption energy of -101.5 kJ mol−1 than Ni (211) of -14.9 kJ mol−1 (Fig. 9a and b), indicating that the introduction of the noble metal Pt can change the surface structures of the transition metal Ni and increase the accessibility of toluene to active sites on the surface of the bimetal catalyst [20]. However, Fig. 9c and d shows that a reduced adsorption energy after Ni introduction to the surface of Pt (211), and similar results are displayed in Fig. 9e and f when Ni atoms are doped into the Pt (111) plane. This simulation results support the desirable catalytic activity of low-Pt bimetal catalysts of PtNi3-C with the dominant amount of Ni to improve the poising devitalization resistance and the catalyst economy and small introduction of Pt to enhance the adsorption energy to toluene and the accessibility of toluene to active sites on the catalyst surface [21]. 4 Conclusions In summary, the samples of PtNi3-C and PtFe3-C were prepared by the chemical reduction method, and their catalytic activity and stability under different conditions were tested on a laboratory-scale reaction bench. The results showed that both two catalysts obtained a good stability of toluene oxidation, while PtFe3-C exhibited a higher catalytic activity than PtNi3-C, which can be ascribed to a higher Pt (0) content of the former. Moreover, the MVK model was used to analyze the reaction kinetics, while the reaction pathway of toluene oxidation was carried out with the MVK mechanism and the in-situ DRIFT. Furthermore, the CASTEP code based on DFT was applied to study the accessibility of reactants to active sites on the surface of bimetal catalysts. Consequently, these results provided a better understanding towards toluene catalytic oxidation over low-Pt catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The low-Pt bimetal compounds (PtNi3-C and PtFe3-C) were synthesized via the chemical reduction method and the toluene catalytic oxidation experiments were conducted to test their catalytic performance. The sample of PtFe3-C (T100 = 255 ℃) possessed a better low-temperature catalytic activity than PtNi3-C (T100 = 288 ℃) due to a higher content of Pt (0), while both two catalysts had a desirable catalytic stability (⁓100 % within 72 h). The reaction kinetic parameters were acquired from the Mars-van Krevelen (MVK) model, and the MVK mechanism combined with the in-situ DRIFT was used to investigate the reaction pathway. Moreover, the theoretical calculations based on DFT was applied to study the accessibility of toluene to the surface of metal atoms doping. Herein, this study not only can provide a promising catalyst with the superior low-temperature catalytic activity and stability, but also can give a comprehensive understanding on the toluene catalytic oxidation mechanism over bimetal catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: A novel viewpoint on the surface adsorbed oxygen and the atom doping in the catalytic oxidation of toluene over low-Pt bimetal catalysts
